text: This report was produced in January 2022 by the United Nations Oﬀice for the Coordination of Humanitarian Aﬀairs
label: BODY

text: (OCHA) Centre for Humanitarian Data in The Hague, which manages the Humanitarian Data Exchange platform (HDX).
label: BODY

text: OCHA thanks all of the organizations that have shared data through HDX, the donors who have supported this work
label: BODY

text: over the years, and the HDX users who are committed to ensuring humanitarian response is data-driven. For
label: BODY

text: additional information, contact the Centre for Humanitarian Data at centrehumdata@un.org.

text: In our third year of producing , we can report steady progress in closing data
label: BODY

text: gaps across most humanitarian operations. This momentum is the result of global advocacy and investment
label: BODY

text: paired with field-level data sharing and outreach. Although the demand for data following the onset of the
label: BODY

text: COVID-19 pandemic has peaked, it remains strong.
label: BODY

text: Our understanding of data availability and use comes from managing the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX), an
label: BODY

text: open platform for finding and sharing data across crises and organizations.1 The data on HDX reflects the reality of
label: BODY

text: the world’s worst humanitarian emergencies, from persistent displacement to a lack of food and shelter for
label: BODY

text: vulnerable populations. The data also shows the response to these crises, from who is providing what assistance
label: BODY

text: to funding levels and more. The UN estimates that 274 million people will need humanitarian assistance and
label: BODY

text: protection in 2022, at a cost of US$41 billion.
label: BODY

text: In 2021, HDX was used by 1.4 million people in 236 countries and territories, maintaining the growth we saw in
label: BODY

text: 2020. Organizations added 2,071 new datasets to the platform, bringing the total to almost 18,500 datasets, which
label: BODY

text: were downloaded over 1.8 million times. Although HDX includes data about all countries in the world, we
label: BODY

text: concentrate here on 27 locations with Humanitarian Response Plans (HRPs).2 In 2021, 35 percent of all datasets
label: BODY

text: downloaded from HDX were related to an HRP location.3
label: BODY

text: At the start of 2022, we estimate that 69 percent of relevant, complete crisis data is available across 27
label: BODY

text: humanitarian operations, based on the analysis of the Data Grids. If we add the data that is relevant but
label: BODY

text: incomplete, the total is 89 percent. This leaves 11 percent of categories with data that does not meet the criteria or
label: BODY

text: with no data. The 27 Data Grids include 482 unique datasets, with a range of 12-22 datasets per location.
label: BODY

text: HRPs are prepared by UN Humanitarian Country Teams in locations where there is an ongoing humanitarian emergency. HRPs are generally
label: BODY

text: prepared annually, and outline an overall strategy and specific activities for each humanitarian cluster or sector.
label: BODY

text: We use Mixpanel, a third-party analytics service, to understand the behavior of users on the HDX platform. We do not send identifying information
label: BODY

text: This report contains details on the data available for each location, category and sub-category covered in the Data
label: BODY

text: Grids as of 31 December 2021. It includes a country deep-dive for Somalia and showcases the work of  the United
label: BODY

text: Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) on population statistics. It also has an assessment of the data required for
label: BODY

text: modelling, specifically for developing anticipatory action trigger mechanisms, with examples from Ethiopia,
label: BODY

text: The HDX Data Grids narrow the focus within each HRP location to a limited set of foundational data needed to
label: BODY

text: understand a humanitarian context. They provide a comparable way to assess data availability across locations and
label: BODY

text: categories and are the basis for the analysis in this report.
label: BODY

text: The Data Grids include six categories: aﬀected people; coordination and context; food security and nutrition;
label: BODY

text: geography and infrastructure; health and education; and population and socio-economy. (See Annex A for definitions.)
label: BODY

text: Data may be included in a Data Grid if it is relevant to the category and sub-national. The data is considered ‘complete’
label: BODY

text: if it has broad geographic coverage, is shared in a commonly used format, and is up-to-date. If any of those criteria are
label: BODY

text: not met, then it is considered ‘incomplete’. The sub-category is complete if it includes at least one dataset that is
label: BODY

text: complete. If the sub-category contains only incomplete datasets, then that sub-category is considered  incomplete. A
label: BODY

text: sub-category is empty if no data meets the above criteria or the data does not exist on HDX. (See Annex B for the Data
label: BODY

text: In 2021, HDX maintained Data Grids for 27 locations and 21 sub-categories. The 27 locations are consistent with 2020,
label: BODY

text: but the number of sub-categories decreased by six. Six were merged into three due to overlapping datasets and three
label: BODY

text: were removed due to a lack of relevance across all locations. (See Annex C for changes to the Data Grids.)
label: BODY

text: We recognize the valuable contributions of all data-sharing organizations publishing data on HDX, and in
label: BODY

text: particular the 20 organizations that populate the Data Grids, with reference to 125 data sources. Datasets included
label: BODY

text: in the Data Grids are downloaded almost four times more than the average dataset on HDX. Trusted partnerships
label: BODY

text: and focused advocacy eﬀorts have led to many new or updated datasets in the Data Grids this year, including:
label: BODY

text: • Sex and age disaggregated population statistics for Burundi with updated projections for 2021, contributed by
label: BODY

text: UNFPA and sourced to the National Statistics Oﬀice.4 (See more on this type of data in Section 8.)
label: BODY

text: • The number of health facilities and their functionality by province in Afghanistan, contributed by OCHA
label: BODY

text: Afghanistan and sourced to WHO. The location of the health facilities is not provided due to the sensitivity of
label: BODY

text: • The number of registered internally displaced people (IDPs) in Burkina Faso at the commune, province and
label: BODY

text: regional level with gender and age breakdown, contributed by OCHA Burkina Faso and sourced to the Conseil
label: BODY

text: National de Secours d’Urgence et de Réhabilitation.6
label: BODY

text: • The location of schools and their status by commune in Mali, contributed by OCHA Mali on behalf of the
label: BODY

text: • Transportation status of roads in the Central African Republic (CAR) indicating the level of diﬀiculty for types of
label: BODY

text: vehicles, contributed by OCHA CAR and compiled by UNDP.8
label: BODY

text: • Joint severity analysis by sector at the district level for Zimbabwe, via OCHA ROSEA on behalf of multiple
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: We hope that our analysis will increase awareness of the data available for humanitarian response activities and
label: BODY

text: draw attention to what is missing within a critical subset of data. Humanitarian crises are dynamic and so is the
label: BODY

text: data needed to understand them. The HDX team will continue to be strong data advocates and work in
label: BODY

text: partnership with the dozens of organizations contributing and using data on the platform. We look forward to
label: BODY

text: continued collaboration and to closing data gaps.
label: BODY

text: • Progress is being made in closing data gaps across most humanitarian operations. This momentum is the
label: BODY

text: result of global advocacy and investment paired with field-level data sharing and outreach.
label: BODY

text: • Although the demand for data following the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic has peaked, it remains strong. In
label: BODY

text: 2021, HDX was used by 1.4 million people in 236 countries and territories. Around 1.8 million datasets were
label: BODY

text: • We estimate that 69 percent or over two-thirds of relevant, complete crisis data is available across 27
label: BODY

text: locations with humanitarian operations, based on the analysis of the HDX Data Grids. If we add the data that
label: BODY

text: is relevant but incomplete, the total is 89 percent. This leaves about 11 percent of the Data Grids with no data.
label: BODY

text: • Afghanistan (86 percent) and CAR (86 percent) have the most complete Data Grids. The next most complete
label: BODY

text: locations are Chad (81 percent), the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) (81 percent), and Sudan (81
label: BODY

text: • Venezuela (43 percent of the sub-categories with no data), Colombia (24 percent of the sub-categories with no
label: BODY

text: data) and Libya (19 percent of the sub-categories with no data) are the countries with the largest data gaps.
label: BODY

text: • Significant improvements were made with the availability of acute malnutrition data (from 19 to 73 percent
label: BODY

text: complete). This is due to outreach with local partners by OCHA field oﬀices.
label: BODY

text: • Datasets included in the Data Grids are downloaded almost four times more than the average dataset on HDX.
label: BODY

text: Ethiopia is the most popular location and geography and infrastructure is the most popular category (as
label: BODY

text: measured by total dataset downloads). The top five user locations were the United States, Pakistan, the
label: BODY

text: • Humanitarian crises are dynamic and so is the data needed to understand them. The availability and
label: BODY

text: completeness of data will fluctuate year-to-year as new data requirements come into focus. Since 2019, we
label: BODY

text: have seen an increase in data completeness from 54 percent to 69 percent and the categories with no data fall
label: BODY

text: from 25 percent to 11 percent (see chart below).
label: BODY

text: • A priority for 2022 will be improving access to forecast, observational and impact data about hazards and
label: BODY

text: shocks. This will be essential to expanding anticipatory action frameworks to more countries with
label: BODY

text: humanitarian operations. To give momentum to these eﬀorts, we will create a new category in the HDX Data
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 4. COMPLETENESS BY LOCATION, CATEGORY AND SUB-CATEGORY
label: HH1

text: Given that the Data Grids became more complete over the course of 2021 (from 51 percent to 69 percent), we can
label: BODY

text: see improvements across location, category and sub-category. Five countries – Burkina Faso, Burundi, DRC, CAR
label: BODY

text: and Sudan – no longer have any sub-categories with missing data. The categories with the most improvement are
label: BODY

text: aﬀected people and population and socio-economy. Overall, the sub-categories with no data have decreased
label: BODY

text: from 25 percent to 11 percent year on year.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Afghanistan and CAR share the highest degree of data completeness at 86 percent. While both locations have
label: BODY

text: incomplete sub-categories, Afghanistan has no data for transportation status in the coordination and context
label: BODY

text: The next most-complete locations for data are Chad (81 percent), DRC (81 percent) and Sudan (81 percent), all of
label: BODY

text: which saw improvements from previous years. Venezuela (43 percent of the sub-categories with no data),
label: BODY

text: Colombia (24 percent of the sub-categories with no data) and Libya (19 percent of the sub-categories with no data)
label: BODY

text: are the countries with the largest data gaps.
label: BODY

text: The most complete categories are aﬀected people (91 percent), population and socio-economy (90 percent) and
label: BODY

text: food security and nutrition (81 percent). Health and education is the least complete category at 46 percent, owing
label: BODY

text: to incomplete data for the location of health and education facilities. The most popular category, in terms of total
label: BODY

text: dataset downloads, is geography and infrastructure.
label: BODY

text: A total of 482 unique datasets are included on the Data Grids. With 21 sub-categories, we would expect a complete
label: BODY

text: Data Grid to include between 21-28 datasets. For the 27 locations covered in this report, the Data Grids include
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: The most complete sub-category is funding, followed by IDPs, refugees and persons of concern, humanitarian
label: BODY

text: needs, food prices, and administrative divisions (all 96 percent complete), owing to the contributions of OCHA,
label: BODY

text: Transportation status (empty in 15 locations) and aﬀected areas (empty in 10 locations) are the most challenging
label: BODY

text: sub-categories to fill. For transportation status, the data should include local transportation routes (e.g., roads,
label: BODY

text: railways, ports) and their current accessibility but the data shared is mostly limited to roads. The aﬀected areas
label: BODY

text: sub-category is filled when there is data on the impact of a rapid onset weather event or on the severity analysis
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: There was significant improvement in the geography and infrastructure category which moved from 40 percent to
label: BODY

text: 67 percent complete due to better maintained data for administrative divisions and populated places.
label: BODY

text: This view of the Data Grids also shows where data is consistently (and centrally) shared across all locations but is
label: BODY

text: considered incomplete (e.g., airports, education facilities, humanitarian access and conflict events). This is the
label: BODY

text: case for secondary or crowd-sourced data that may not be the best available or is limited in coverage.

label: BODY

text: There has been steady progress with the Somalia Data Grid over the past year. Overall data completeness
label: BODY

text: improved from 56 percent to 76 percent, with only one sub-category missing data (populated places). The
label: BODY

text: Somalia Data Grid includes 19 datasets shared by 10 organizations. Together, these datasets were downloaded
label: BODY

text: 6,411 times in 2021. The most popular dataset is the Somalia administrative boundaries.
label: BODY

text: Somalia has two complete categories: aﬀected people, and food security and nutrition. The Food Security and
label: BODY

text: Nutrition Analysis Unit at FAO newly shared data (via the Somalia Nutrition Cluster) on acute malnutrition by
label: BODY

text: district. Other new additions to this Data Grid are the location of airstrips from the Logistics Cluster and
label: BODY

text: transportation status from WFP. The OCHA Somalia oﬀice has played an important role in engaging local partners
label: BODY

text: on data sharing and maintenance, with positive results.
label: BODY

text: 8. ORGANIZATION DEEP DIVE: UNITED NATIONS POPULATION FUND
label: HH1

text: Population statistics are the starting point for estimating the number of people aﬀected by a humanitarian crisis.
label: BODY

text: As part of its reproductive health mission, UNFPA works to strengthen national population data systems. Over the
label: BODY

text: last several years, UNFPA and OCHA have partnered to ensure that sex and age disaggregated population data is
label: BODY

text: accessible to the humanitarian community, and we can see the progress by looking at HDX.
label: BODY

text: The data collaboration with UNFPA is focused on countries experiencing or at risk of a humanitarian crisis. For
label: BODY

text: these locations, OCHA oversees the common operational datasets (CODs), which are authoritative reference data
label: BODY

text: used to support operations and decision-making in a humanitarian emergency.    The CODs include administrative
label: BODY

text: boundaries, which are part of the geography and infrastructure category of the HDX Data Grids, and population
label: BODY

text: statistics, which are part of the population and socio-economy category.
label: BODY

text: In 2021, UNFPA became the lead agency for the COD population statistics datasets. They combine demographic
label: BODY

text: expertise with working relationships with national statistical agencies to identify, validate, and if necessary project
label: BODY

text: the best available statistics. These datasets are given a ‘reference year’ referring to the year for which the data was
label: BODY

text: originally collected (normally a census year) or to which it has been projected.
label: BODY

text: UNFPA began sharing COD population statistics on HDX in late 2020.   Over the past year, 50 datasets have been
label: BODY

text: added covering 49 countries. Five of these datasets are included in the Data Grids for Burundi, Chad, Myanmar,
label: BODY

text: Nigeria and Zimbabwe. The rest of UNFPA's current population datasets on HDX are for non-HRP locations that
label: BODY

text: may be at risk of a humanitarian crisis. In 2022, UNFPA plans to update population datasets for sudden onset
label: BODY

text: crises (as they did for Tonga following the recent volcanic eruption   ) and will continue projecting the oldest
label: BODY

text: census data to the current year.
label: BODY

text: See the IASC Guidelines for Common Operational Datasets in Disaster Preparedness and Response (2010) for more details. The CODs are managed
label: BODY

text: at the global level by OCHA’s Field Information Services Section and at the field level by OCHA Information Management Oﬀicers in consultation
label: BODY

text: CODs also include humanitarian profile datasets, which are established afer the onset of a crisis and include the location of displaced people,
label: BODY

text: and country-specific CODs which have local relevance.
label: BODY

text: Out of the 298 organizations sharing data on HDX, 20 contribute data that is included in the Data Grids.   This is a
label: BODY

text: reduction in the number of organizations from past years, mainly due to a decrease in the number of Data Grid
label: BODY

text: sub-categories (from 27 to 21). An organization’s dataset may also be removed from the Data Grids if it is no longer
label: BODY

text: timely or has been superseded by a more relevant dataset. The 20 contributing organizations are sharing data
label: BODY

text: OCHA is counted as a single organization even though 31 field oﬀices   and two entities at Headquarters contribute
label: BODY

text: data to HDX. In total, OCHA field oﬀices contributed 185 datasets or 38 percent of all data in the Data Grids. For
label: BODY

text: each HRP location, the OCHA oﬀice almost always contributes the top downloaded data. For total downloads
label: BODY

text: across all 27 locations, the data from OCHA’s Financial Tracking Service (FTS) and IOM are the most popular.
label: BODY

text: Since 2015, the Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED) has shared important data on conflict events
label: BODY

text: for almost 200 locations around the world. In 2021, ACLED changed the frequency of the data they make available
label: BODY

text: on HDX from daily to weekly. The data now has the total number of reported political violence, civilian-targeting,
label: BODY

text: and demonstration events per week, per country. ACLED makes the real-time datasets available through a
label: BODY

text: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project
label: BODY

text: Food Security and Nutrition Working Group, West and Central Africa
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: An organization on HDX can be a legal entity or an informal group and may be listed as the source or the contributor of the dataset. The entities listed in
label: BODY

text: this section have created organizations on HDX and manage their data directly. Although most organizations are both the source and contributor for the
label: BODY

text: data, there are cases where this varies. For instance, as part of its coordination role, OCHA aggregates and shares data on humanitarian needs but the data
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Anticipatory action enables humanitarian organizations to provide assistance before a shock occurs, reducing the
label: BODY

text: impact of a crisis on the lives of aﬀected people. Since early 2020, OCHA has been testing the practicalities of
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action through pilots in 12 countries.   Each pilot has an anticipatory action framework with three
label: BODY

text: elements: a forecast-based trigger mechanism embedded in a decision-making process (the model); a pre-agreed
label: BODY

text: action plan (the delivery); and pre-arranged finance (the money, in this case from the UN Central Emergency
label: BODY

text: The Centre’s predictive analytics team has been supporting this work through the development of the trigger
label: BODY

text: mechanisms. A trigger mechanism translates the characteristics of a hazard or a shock and its impact (food
label: BODY

text: insecurity or damaged housing) into technical specifications.   These specifications are the basis for the action
label: BODY

text: Triggers can include both observational data, such as water levels, and predictive elements, such as flood
label: BODY

text: forecasts. A trigger is designed to provide partners with a window of opportunity to take action while balancing
label: BODY

text: Designing a trigger requires access to three types of data:
label: BODY

text: 1. Current and historical data about the hazard;
label: BODY

text: 2. Data about the historical and expected impact of the hazard and shock; and
label: BODY

text: Despite progress in filling data gaps in 2021, the availability and usability of this type of data remains a major
label: BODY

text: barrier to implementing anticipatory action in many humanitarian contexts. There has been suﬀicient data for
label: BODY

text: the existing OCHA pilots but expanding anticipatory action to new HRP locations will be challenging without
label: BODY

text: Below we provide a closer look at the data needed for developing triggers based on our experience with several
label: BODY

text: countries, including Ethiopia, Malawi, Nepal and the Philippines. While we touch on the DRC and Mozambique,
label: BODY

text: the work to anticipate cholera is ongoing so we have not included these countries in the data availability table.
label: BODY

text: Current and historical data about a hazard is required to model the likelihood of the event occurring. This data
label: BODY

text: includes weather and climate observations and disease surveillance, as well as lists of recorded historical events,
label: BODY

text: which are ofen incomplete or hard to access.
label: BODY

text: In Ethiopia, for example, despite the number of actors producing early warning analysis for drought in the Horn
label: BODY

text: of Africa, there is no consensus on the exact definition of what should be considered a drought. As a result, there
label: BODY

text: was no agreed-upon reference list of historical drought years, which was needed to establish a trigger threshold
label: BODY

text: Similarly, in Malawi, there was no reference dataset to understand the frequency and patterns of dry spells
label: BODY

text: aﬀecting the southern region of the country, primarily due to a lack of consensus around the definition of the
label: BODY

text: shock. To fill this gap, we have analyzed and made available on HDX    over 20 years of historical sub-national
label: BODY

text: rainfall data to better understand when and where dry spells took place.
label: BODY

text: The 12 pilots are: Bangladesh (floods), Burkina Faso (drought), Chad (drought), DRC (cholera), Ethiopia (drought), Madagascar (plague), Malawi
label: BODY

text: (dry spells), Mozambique (cholera), Nepal (floods), Niger (drought), Somalia (drought), and The Philippines (typhoons).
label: BODY

text: In this report we refer to ‘hazard’ as the potential source of harm (e.g., a flood) which generates a ‘shock’ (e.g., water level above a certain
label: BODY

text: threshold) that has an impact on vulnerable people (e.g., crop losses or housing destruction).
label: BODY

text: To evaluate the trigger we used historical rainfall data and food security data. The Ethiopia trigger has been independently evaluated by the Red
label: BODY

text: For anticipating cholera in the DRC and Mozambique, it was challenging to find datasets listing all past outbreaks.
label: BODY

text: When the data was available, it was provided in multiple PDF reports, requiring significant eﬀort to make it usable
label: BODY

text: Data linking previous shocks to their impact on vulnerable populations is essential for the design of an anticipatory
label: BODY

text: action trigger. With this data in hand, it is possible to model the expected impact of a future shock.
label: BODY

text: In the Philippines, historical data on housing damage from previous typhoons was foundational for developing
label: BODY

text: an impact model based on forecasted typhoon tracks. In Nepal, the list of historical floods was estimated using
label: BODY

text: data on water levels but it was diﬀicult to estimate the severity of these events (i.e., the number of people aﬀected
label: BODY

text: or the houses destroyed by the flood). In Malawi, OCHA conducted a survey and interviews to better understand
label: BODY

text: the impact of past dry spells.
label: BODY

text: Access to impact data is one of the main limitations in implementing anticipatory action in countries with
label: BODY

text: humanitarian operations. There are consistent gaps in data on the impact of hazards on vulnerable populations.
label: BODY

text: Even when this data is available, it is unlikely to be machine readable, sub-national and/or include relevant
label: BODY

text: These findings correspond with the completeness levels of the aﬀected areas sub-category in the Data Grids,
label: BODY

text: where 10 out of the 27 HRP locations are missing data. Where this data does exist, it may only refer to a recent
label: BODY

text: shock (i.e., a flood in South Sudan   ) or be part of a broader severity analysis conducted for the Humanitarian
label: BODY

text: Current forecast data is provided globally, with projections for riverine floods, seasonal rainfall forecasts, or major
label: BODY

text: storms; or at the regional and national level, with projections for specific countries or areas. In addition, historical
label: BODY

text: forecasts are used to better understand model performance and the lead time that these models could provide as
label: BODY

text: part of an anticipatory action plan.
label: BODY

text: Accessing forecast data in a machine-readable format is a challenge. In the Philippines, we relied on global data
label: BODY

text: providers. In Nepal, national authorities provided qualitative flood early warning information, which had to be
label: BODY

text: extracted and translated from social media and the Government’s website. The challenge can be even greater
label: BODY

text: when looking for historical forecast data. It is either not available or has very limited geographic or temporal
label: BODY

text: coverage. For Nepal, we found that national authorities did not keep a record of historical flood forecasts, which
label: BODY

text: was needed to evaluate the forecasting skills and lead time of the model.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: The anticipatory action pilots have demonstrated the promise of getting ahead of crises before they escalate by
label: BODY

text: using diﬀerent analytical approaches to predict out-of-the-ordinary events and their projected impact on
label: BODY

text: vulnerable people. This approach is enabled by the growing availability and quality of forecast data as well as the
label: BODY

text: increasing awareness of humanitarian actors of the opportunities it provides.
label: BODY

text: Access to forecast, observational and impact data about hazards and shocks will be essential to expanding
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action frameworks to more countries with humanitarian operations. To help humanitarian actors
label: BODY

text: better assess the feasibility of anticipatory action in diﬀerent contexts, the Centre is developing a checklist for
label: BODY

text: trigger mechanisms. This will include data requirements in addition to other factors such as local capacity and
label: BODY

text: Beyond anticipatory action, more robust weather and climate data is needed to understand the near and
label: BODY

text: medium-term eﬀects of the climate crisis on humanitarian operations. Access to relevant data and evidence about
label: BODY

text: the humanitarian impacts of climate change is key to helping extend the annual time horizon humanitarians
label: BODY

text: To give momentum to these eﬀorts, we will create a new category in the HDX Data Grids that includes the types of
label: BODY

text: data detailed above. We will also work with researchers to fill known data gaps by developing reference lists of
label: BODY

text: historical hazards and their impact for priority countries.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: We will continue to update the Data Grids throughout the year as organizations share new, relevant data. The
label: BODY

text: current status for each location is always available on HDX, both on the relevant location page and on the
label: BODY

text: Overview of Data Grids page.   As part of our internal Data Grid Governance Group, we will regularly review the
label: BODY

text: categories and sub-categories to see if they should be removed or expanded. A priority for 2022 will be improving
label: BODY

text: access to forecast, observational and impact data about hazards and shocks for anticipatory action. We welcome
label: BODY

text: feedback on possible improvements. Please be in touch with questions or comments at centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: ANNEX A: DATA GRID SUB-CATEGORY DEFINITIONS
label: HH1

text: Tabular data of the number of displaced people by location or vector or tabular data with coordinates
label: BODY

text: representing the locations at which displaced people are gathered. Locations can be administrative
label: BODY

text: divisions or other locations (such as camps) if an additional dataset defining those locations is also
label: BODY

text: Tabular data of the number of refugees and persons of concern either in the country or originating
label: BODY

text: from the country disaggregated by their current location. Locations can be administrative divisions or
label: BODY

text: other locations (such as camps) if an additional dataset defining those locations is also available or if
label: BODY

text: the locations' coordinates are defined in the tabular data.
label: BODY

text: Tabular data of the number of displaced people who have returned.
label: BODY

text: Tabular data of the number of people in need of humanitarian assistance by location and
label: BODY

text: List of organizations working on humanitarian issues, by humanitarian cluster/sector and
label: BODY

text: Tabular data listing the amount of funding provided by humanitarian cluster/sector.
label: BODY

text: Vector data or tabular data by administrative division which describes the type and/or severity of
label: BODY

text: Vector data or tabular data with coordinates describing the location, date, and type of conflict event.
label: BODY

text: Tabular or vector data describing the location of natural hazards, permissions, active fighting, or other
label: BODY

text: access constraints that impact the delivery of humanitarian interventions.
label: BODY

text: Vector or tabular data representing local transportation routes with an indication of status or current
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Vector data representing the IPC phase classification or tabular data representing population or
label: BODY

text: percentage of population by IPC phase and administrative division.
label: BODY

text: Tabular data specifying the global acute malnutrition (GAM) rate or severe acute malnutrition (SAM)
label: BODY

text: Time series prices for common food commodities at a set of locations.
label: BODY

text: Vector geographic data describing the sub-national administrative divisions of a location, usually a
label: BODY

text: country, including the names and unique identifiers, usually p-codes, of each administrative division.
label: BODY

text: To be considered ‘complete’, and included here, the humanitarian community working in the location
label: BODY

text: has to have endorsed a preferred set of administrative boundaries as the Common Operational
label: BODY

text: Vector data or tabular data with coordinates representing the location of populated places (cities,
label: BODY

text: Geographic data describing the location of roads with some indication of the importance of each
label: BODY

text: road segment in the transportation network. The data should exclude or indicate roads that are not
label: BODY

text: usable by typical four-wheel-drive vehicles (footpaths, etc.).
label: BODY

text: Geographic data representing all operational airports including a name or other unique identifier and
label: BODY

text: an indication of what types of aircraf can use each.
label: BODY

text: Vector data or tabular data with coordinates representing health facilities with some indication of the
label: BODY

text: Vector data or tabular data with coordinates representing education facilities with some indication of
label: BODY

text: the type of facility (school, university, etc.).
label: BODY

text: Total population disaggregated age and sex categories, aggregated by administrative division.
label: BODY

text: Population living under a defined poverty threshold, aggregated by administrative division and
label: BODY

text: represented as a percentage of total population or as an absolute number.

text: ANNEX B: INCLUSION OF DATA IN THE DATA GRIDS
label: BODY

text: Data Grid curation involves the careful evaluation of datasets on HDX for inclusion in one or more of the
label: BODY

text: sub-categories in accordance with a standard criteria. The HDX team conducts this evaluation when a dataset is
label: BODY

text: newly added or updated on HDX.
label: BODY

text: The HDX team supports the Data Grids in three ways:
label: BODY

text: 1. Reviewing whether any dataset on HDX could be added to a Data Grid;
label: BODY

text: 2. Conducting targeted outreach with humanitarian organizations to find relevant datasets; and
label: BODY

text: 3. Identifying potential datasets with partners in the research community, academia and/or government
label: BODY

text: The first step in determining whether a dataset should be included in a Data Grid is to check whether the dataset
label: BODY

text: meets this thematic requirement defined in Annex A. Datasets that are not considered relevant are automatically
label: BODY

text: The second step is to determine if the dataset is sub-national. To fulfil this requirement the data must be
label: BODY

text: disaggregated to at least the first administrative division. If the data is only available at the national level, it is
label: BODY

text: typically excluded. The sub-national requirement has been partially or completely waived for three datasets:
label: BODY

text: UNHCR’s data on forcibly displaced populations and stateless persons; OCHA FTS’s requirements and funding
label: BODY

text: data; and IATI activities data. For information about the decision-making process for sub-national waivers, see
label: BODY

text: The third step is to assess whether a thematically relevant, sub-national data set is complete or incomplete. A
label: BODY

text: dataset is considered complete if it satisfies all of the following criteria:
label: BODY

text: 2. Available in commonly used formats; and
label: BODY

text: If the dataset does not satisfy one or more of these criteria, it is considered incomplete.
label: BODY

text: Finally, the dataset is compared against existing datasets for that location to determine if it should be added to
label: BODY

text: the Data Grid. If the sub-category is empty, or if the data would complement other datasets in a sub-category, the
label: BODY

text: HDX team will add it to the Data Grid. A complementary dataset is one that adds unique and useful information to
label: BODY

text: The IATI datasets are a good example of a complementary dataset as they add unique and useful information to
label: BODY

text: the 3W sub-category. Another example is a dataset that provides data for a geographic area not covered by the
label: BODY

text: existing dataset. If there is already a complete dataset available for the sub-category, the HDX team will reach out
label: BODY

text: to in-country partners to determine which dataset is being used operationally and that dataset will be included in
label: BODY

text: The sub-category is considered complete if it has at least one complete dataset available for the sub-category. If
label: BODY

text: the sub-category contains only incomplete datasets, then that sub-category is considered incomplete. Overall
label: BODY

text: category completeness refers to the proportion of sub-categories in the category that are complete. Similarly,
label: BODY

text: completeness for a location refers to the proportion of sub-categories that are complete in the location.
label: BODY

text: Sub-categories are considered empty if no datasets on HDX meet the above-mentioned criteria. In general, data
label: BODY

text: can be missing for three reasons:
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data   centre.humdata.org    |    Join our mailing list   bit.ly/humdatamailing    |    Twitter   @humdata    |    Email   centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: 1. It is not collected (e.g., because nobody is present to do so, because it is unsafe to access areas to collect
label: BODY

text: it, because it requires investment and resources that are not available, or because nobody prioritizes it as
label: BODY

text: 2. It is collected but not publicly shared (e.g. because the collecting organization does not have an open
label: BODY

text: data policy, because the data is sensitive and should not be shared, because the collecting entity fears
label: BODY

text: sharing the data with actors they do not know and trust, or because of a lack of resources to clean and
label: BODY

text: 3. It is collected and shared but is not shared on HDX, or known about by the HDX team.
label: BODY

text: The criteria for evaluating completeness for relevant, sub-national data are detailed below:
label: BODY

text: Does the data have broad geographic coverage with explicit location information?
label: BODY

text: •  Is the dataset geographically comprehensive, or as comprehensive as possible? If the dataset is
label: BODY

text: disaggregated by administrative divisions, does it cover all of them? If it does not, is the meaning of a
label: BODY

text: missing administrative division defined in the metadata? If there is no comprehensive list to compare
label: BODY

text: against (for example, with spontaneous displacement locations), does the dataset make it clear if it
label: BODY

text: attempts to be comprehensive or not?
label: BODY

text: •  Are location references defined? The dataset should contain explicit geographic data (i.e., Geographic
label: BODY

text: Information System data or tabular data with latitude and longitude fields). If not, the dataset should be
label: BODY

text: joinable to an available dataset that defines those locations.
label: BODY

text: Is the data in commonly-used formats?
label: HH1

text: •  Is it stored in a common file format? We include CSV, XLS, XLSX, SHP, GEOJSON, etc. Formats like GPKG
label: BODY

text: and others that are more diﬀicult for the typical humanitarian data specialist would be marked
label: BODY

text: •  Is the data tidy? Field names and data rows should be easy to determine. There should not be sub-total
label: BODY

text: rows interspersed with data rows. The required data for the category should be in a single table on the
label: BODY

text: same tab. For tabular data with coordinates, the x and y columns (usually longitude and latitude) should
label: BODY

text: be in decimal degree format and separated into two columns.
label: BODY

text: •  Has the dataset become out of date? Depending on how frequently the dataset is expected to be
label: BODY

text: updated, the HDX team considers the age of the data and whether the dataset should have been
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: ANNEX C: CHANGES TO THE DATA GRIDS
label: HH1

text: A consistent focus of our work over the last year has been soliciting feedback from OCHA field oﬀices and partner
label: BODY

text: organizations to ensure that the data requirements and criteria used to curate the Data Grids reflect data needs in
label: BODY

text: We established an internal Data Grid Governance Group to discuss feedback and improvements and make
label: BODY

text: decisions around changes to the Data Grids. In 2021, the Data Grid Governance Group met three times and
label: BODY

text: 1. Crowdsourced data may be considered complete on a case-by-case basis.
label: HH1

text: Previously, all crowdsourced datasets were automatically considered incomplete because this data collection
label: BODY

text: methodology makes it diﬀicult to determine how up-to-date and comprehensive the data is. The Data Grid
label: BODY

text: Governance Group determined that crowdsourced data would be considered complete if an OCHA field oﬀice
label: BODY

text: confirms that the data is the best available and is being used operationally.
label: BODY

text: 2. HDX Connect datasets can be included in the Data Grids and considered complete if they have been
label: H4

text: HDX Connect is a feature that enables organizations to share metadata only and make the underlying data
label: BODY

text: available by request. This ensures that organizations can verify who can access the data in sensitive contexts. The
label: BODY

text: Data Grid Governance Group determined that as long as the HDX team has reviewed the dataset and assessed it
label: BODY

text: against the criteria for inclusion in the Data Grids, that data can be considered complete.
label: BODY

text: The Data Grid Governance Group reviewed all sub-categories and the data within them, and agreed to the
label: BODY

text: a. The humanitarian profile locations sub-category was merged into the internally displaced persons
label: BODY

text: sub-category and the definition was updated to encompass elements of both.
label: BODY

text: b. The baseline population by sex and age was merged into the baseline population sub-category and the
label: BODY

text: definition was updated to require sex and age dissaggregation.
label: BODY

text: c. GAM and SAM were merged into a new acute malnutrition sub-category. This new sub-category can be
label: BODY

text: satisfied with data specifying either GAM or SAM rates.
label: BODY

text: d. The sub-categories for casualties, aﬀected schools, and damaged and destroyed buildings were removed
label: BODY

text: due to a lack of relevance across all locations. They were therefore not a consistent measure for
label: BODY

text: 4. Waiver of sub-national requirement for inclusion in the Data Grid.
label: HH1

text: The UNHCR data on forcibly displaced populations and stateless persons was previously excluded from the
label: BODY

text: refugees and persons of concern sub-category because it was not sub-national. We received feedback that
label: BODY

text: because refugee status is based on crossing national borders, refugee statistics are typically available and used at
label: BODY

text: the national rather than sub-national level. The Data Grid Governance Group determined that this data is the best
label: BODY

text: available and granted a waiver to include it as complete for the sub-category. A similar sub-national waiver is in
label: BODY

text: place for the OCHA FTS requirements and funding data, since it is considered the best available, and for the IATI
label: BODY

text: aid activities datasets, which are assessed as incomplete but considered a complimentary dataset to the 3W.
label: BODY

text: The Data Grid Governance Group agreed to allow ‘Not Applicable’ to be used when the sub-category is not
label: BODY

text: relevant in a given context. This was applied to the following locations and sub-categories: Ukraine - acute
label: BODY

text: malnutrition; Ukraine - refugees and persons of concern; Ukraine - returnees; and State of Palestine - returnees.
label: BODY
